moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 c5 4. d5 exd5:
One of the debates that is currently being discussed in benoni circles is whether or not white should delay playing the f-knight
Alternative variation: For example ] 6. e4 g6 7. f4 Bg7 (7... Qe7 8. Nf3 Bg4)8. Bb5+ Nbd7 [ we have a hybrid four pawns attack]
moves.6... g6 7. e4 Bg7 8. Bf4: If I remember correctly this is what I played against Stahandske in our last game(colors reversed) in the Benoni game. If you want a deeper review of the in-and-outs of the Bf4 variation then may I direct your attention to that game. http://gameknot.com/annotation.pl/golden-rules-of-rook-endings?gm=50122. But I am glad he played it as white because it allowed me to demonstrate how I would handle the tricky 8.Bf4.
moves.8... O-O:
I was intending to play... but forgot about it during the game.
Alternative variation: 8... a6 [!?] 9. Qa4+ Bd7 10. Qb3 b5 [!?][ to highlight the main drawback of 8.Bf4 which is that white can not stop black from developing a strong initiative on the queen side. ]
moves.9. Bd3:
?
As a general rule white should never allow black to play ...Bg4 successfully. 
Alternative variation: 9. Nd2 [!][ the typical move in the Bf4 lines. The white knight wants to go to c4. ] 9... Ng4 [!?][the main response to Nd2. Black  takes direct aim at cutting off white's plan of planting a knight on c4. ] 10. Be2 Ne5 11. O-O f5 [⩲]

Alternative variation: 9. h3 [?] 9... Re8 10. Nd2 Nxe4 11. Ncxe4 f5 12. Be2 fxe4 13. Nc4 Qf6
moves.9... Bg4 10. h3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 Qe7: Alternative variation: [I did not see much gain in] 11... Nh5 [!?] 12. Bh2 Qe7 13. O-O Nd7 14. g4 Nhf6 [=]
moves.12... Nbd7: Alternative variation: [I did not like ...Nh5 due to the fact that white could exchange the DSB's so early in the game. ] 12... Nh5 [?!] 13. Bg5 f6 14. Bh6 Bxh6 15. Qxh6
moves.13. O-O a6 14. g4:
I like this move it puts a lot of pressure on black's seriously cramped king side. 
Alternative variation: 14. Qg3 Ne5 15. Bxe5 dxe5 16. Qe3 b5 [∞]
moves.14... b5 15. Qg3:
!
pinning black down to the defense of d6.
moves.15... Ne8: the knight sits awkwardly on e8 disrupting the communications on black's back rank.
moves.16. Rfe1: white is trying to push through e4-e5. So black has to get going
moves.16... b4:
!
White threatens in the centre and black punches back on the wing.
moves.17. Nd1 Ne5: Blockading the e4 pawn and threatening ...c4
moves.18. a3: Alternative variation: 18. Bxe5 Bxe5 19. f4 Bd4+ 20. Kh1 [⩱]
moves.18... bxa3 19. Rxa3 Nc7: defending the a-pawn and improving the knight position
moves.20. Nc3 Rfb8: challenging white for control of the b-file
moves.21. Rb1 Rb4:
!
Lifting the rook and controlling massive amount of space in the enemy camp.
moves.22. h4:
white goes for broke but he does not have the time and space to do it. 
Alternative variation: 22. Bc2 g5 23. Bc1 Ng6 [∓]
moves.23. Bxd6 Qd7 24. Bxc7 Nxb2: Now all of the sudden the black DSB has become a monster and the knight on c3 is a sitting duck!
moves.25. Bf4 Nc4 26. Raa1 a5: The white queen and bishop sit haplessly on the other side of the board as the action builds on the queen side.
moves.27. Kf1:
?
surely to goodness white has a more active move!
